fields.value: Project Report on study of CIPIC HRTF Database

dsDescriptionValue.value: This project describes a public-domain database of high-spatial-resolution head-related transfer functions measured. Head Related Transfer Function (HRTF) characterizes the auditory cues created by scattering of sound off a person’s anatomy. While it is known that features in the HRTF can be associated with various phenomena, such as head diffraction, head and torso reflection, knee reflection and pinna resonances and anti-resonances, identification of these phenomena are usually qualitative and/or heuristic. The objective of this project is to attempt to decompose the HRTF and extract significant features that are perceptually important for source localization. Some of the significant features that have been identified are the pinna resonances and the notches in the spectrum caused by various parts of the body.

publicationCitation.value: Manu Mitra Project Report on study of CIPIC HRTF Database. University of Bridgeport (2009)

files.description: This project describes a public-domain database of high-spatial-resolution head-related transfer functions measured. Some of the significant features that have been identified are the pinna resonances and the notches in the spectrum caused by various parts of the body.

dataFile.description: This project describes a public-domain database of high-spatial-resolution head-related transfer functions measured. Head Related Transfer Function (HRTF) characterizes the auditory cues created by scattering of sound off a person’s anatomy. While it is known that features in the HRTF can be associated with various phenomena, such as head diffraction, head and torso reflection, knee reflection and pinna resonances and anti-resonances, identification of these phenomena are usually qualitative and/or heuristic. The objective of this project is to attempt to decompose the HRTF and extract significant features that are perceptually important for source localization. Some of the significant features that have been identified are the pinna resonances and the notches in the spectrum caused by various parts of the body.
